results.title: An Interview with Glenn James
results.brief_description: When Glenn James’ fellow soldiers returned from service in Vietnam, they told him they finally understood what it was like to be Indigenous - you get treated like rubbish. Vietnam soldiers were brought home under the cover of night and at best ignored. For James, this was nothing new. As he talks about the plight of others that he has committed his life to helping, James provides some insight into an indomitable spirit, and how he has focused his energy into creating positive change for others.
results.description: When Glenn James’ fellow soldiers returned from service in Vietnam, they told him they finally understood what it was like to be Indigenous - you get treated like rubbish. results.title: An Interview with Harold Brown
results.brief_description: Harold Brown reflects fondly on his time in the army. Joining the artillery division in 1942, he was posted to Bougainville, where disease was more of a threat to the soldiers than the Japanese. Despite longing to be back home with his newborn son, Brown could not have wished to be with a better crew.

results.title: An Interview with Alan Clark
results.brief_description: On the 16th May, 1941, Alan Clark was called up to serve for Australia in World War II. He tells of his time training in New South Wales, his decision to join the Air Force and the precise skill involved with dropping mines.

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [November 2010]
results.brief_description: Nine Victorian war veterans tell of their experiences through the creation of digital stories, as part of ACMI’s Digital Storytelling workshop. While the horror and dangers and residual trauma of war are evident, these stories also pay tribute to the qualities of mateship and bravery instilled in them by the experience.

results.title: Wake up call
results.creator_credit: Jack Pearce, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: While Jack Pearce may have missed the war, there was still plenty of dangerous work for him to do, clearing mines up the Queensland coast for the Australian Navy.

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [September 2010]
results.brief_description: ACMI’s Digital Storytelling unit interviewed ten Victorian war veterans for their perspectives on life in the army, being involved in war in a different country and adjusting to life back in Australia. The personal experiences of these soldiers provide a moving memoir and a compelling historical account of Australia in wartime.
results.title_for_label: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [September 2010]
results.description: ACMI’s Digital Storytelling unit interviewed ten Victorian war veterans for their perspectives on life in the army, being involved in war in a different country and adjusting to life back in Australia. The personal experiences of these soldiers provide a moving memoir and a compelling historical account of Australia in wartime.

The personal experiences of these soldiers provide a moving memoir and a compelling historical account of Australia in wartime.

results.title: Packages from home
results.creator_credit: Dave Piggott, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Dave Piggott went to fight in the Vietnam War at 19, it was a very different world to life back in Australia. With the help of the friends he made in the army, he soon got used to life there and it’s the funny stories and good friends that remain with him today.

results.title: An Interview with Jack Jones
results.brief_description: Born in Ascot Vale, Jack Jones was only fifteen when Menzies declared war so he had to wait till 1942 before he could sign up. Put through extensive training he was posted in New Guinea and, later, Bougainville, where they had to wait for four months after the war ended to be brought home. While some of his colleagues went ‘troppo’, Jones coped by seeing his time in the war as a job.
results.description: Born in Ascot Vale, Jack Jones was only fifteen when Menzies declared war so he had to wait till 1942 before he could sign up. While some of his colleagues went ‘troppo’, Jones coped by seeing his time in the war as a job.

results.title: An Interview with Frank Cox
results.brief_description: Frank Cox signed up to joined the army to see what they had in store for him. He started work as a dispatch rider in Palestine and finished up in the Suez Canal as part of his training. After serving in Tobruk and Greece, Cox became a prisoner of war and has borne witness to the suffering of his colleagues.
results.description: Frank Cox signed up to joined the army to see what they had in store for him. After serving in Tobruk and Greece, Cox became a prisoner of war and has borne witness to the suffering of his colleagues.
